title: 115_hr2129
content:
The "Climate Change Adapt America Fund Act of 2017" establishes a Climate Change Advisory Commission and an Adapt America Fund. It includes definitions, duties of the commission, personnel matters, funding, and termination. The Act also addresses compliance with the Davis-Bacon Act, climate change obligations, and promotion. The Act establishes the Climate Change Advisory Commission and the Adapt America Fund. The Commission is defined as the Climate Change Advisory Commission, and the Fund is defined as the Adapt America Fund. A qualified climate change adaptation purpose aims to reduce the impact of climate change through infrastructure resiliency, disaster response, and mitigation. The Act establishes the Climate Change Advisory Commission and the Adapt America Fund, with a focus on infrastructure resiliency, disaster response, and ecosystem protection. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce. Establishment of Climate Change Advisory Commission. The "Climate Change Advisory Commission" is established with 11 members selected from various sectors and institutions of higher education. The members are appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. The Climate Change Advisory Commission consists of 11 members appointed by various leaders. Each member serves for the life of the Commission and must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and meetings are called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making. The Climate Change Advisory Commission consists of 11 members appointed by various leaders. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making, but a lesser number can hold hearings. The Commission selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. SEC. 102. DUTIES. The Commission will establish recommendations for a Federal investment program funded by revenue from climate change obligations. This program will focus on improving and adapting energy, transportation, water, and general infrastructure impacted by climate variability. It will prioritize projects that enhance infrastructure resiliency using the best available science and data. Additionally, the Commission will identify cost-effective investments that provide multiple benefits. The Commission will prioritize investments and projects that provide multiple benefits to commerce, human health, and ecosystems. SEC. 103. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal employees or non-federal employees. Non-federal employees receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while federal employees serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided for Commission members. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws and set their compensation. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint personnel and set their compensation, with a maximum pay rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will use funds from the Fund for administrative expenses and will terminate after completing its duties. Title II introduces the Adapt America Fund. The "Adapt America Fund" is established within the Department of Commerce to assist in implementing climate change adaptation projects. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, will provide funds to eligible entities such as Federal agencies, States, local governments, and utility districts for qualified climate change adaptation purposes. The "Adapt America Fund" established by the Department of Commerce provides funds to eligible entities for climate change adaptation projects. Eligible entities include governments, utility districts, tribal governments, transit agencies, nonprofit organizations, special purpose districts, and others determined by the Secretary. Entities must submit applications containing project details and expected benefits for selection by the Secretary based on specific criteria. Entities eligible for funds must adhere to criteria set by the Commission. They are required to provide at least 25% of the project funds themselves. The funds deposited in the Fund must be used for new projects only. Federal laws and regulations still apply to projects receiving funds under this Act. SEC. 202 of the Act requires contractors and subcontractors on projects funded by the Fund to pay laborers and mechanics prevailing wages. The Secretary of Labor determines these rates. SEC. 203 states that the Secretary will use available funds for program implementation. TITLE III--REVENUE

SEC. 301. CLIMATE CHANGE OBLIGATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue climate change obligations within 6 months of this Act, with proceeds deposited in the Fund. These obligations will be backed by the full faith and credit of the United States and exempt from local taxation. The Secretary will issue climate change obligations annually totaling $200,000,000, using available funds for this purpose. The Secretary will promote the purchase of climate change obligations with a budget not exceeding $10,000,000 annually from 2018 to 2022. Additionally, the Secretary can accept donated advertising for this purpose. $10,000,000 is authorized for appropriations each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022 to support this promotion.
